SEDUCTIVE JOURNEY: American Tourists in France From Jefferson to the Jazz Age. By Harvey Levenstein. (University of Chicago, $30.) Americans' changing views of France and what delights can be found there are the subjects of this masterly cultural history.

THE SEEKERS: The Story of Man's Continuing Quest to Understand His World. By Daniel J. Boorstin. (Random House, $25.95.) A synoptic overview of the history of Western religion and philosophy that reminds us what history on the grand narrative scale looks like, by a former Librarian of Congress and formidable scholar who has won most of the prizes historians can get.

SHAKESPEARE: The Invention of the Human. By Harold Bloom. (Riverhead, $35.) Bloom, whose scholarship yields to no one, argues that Shakespeare's inward characters have formed our minds, creating kinds of consciousness that didn't exist before, say, Hamlet and Falstaff.

THE SHAMEFUL LIFE OF SALVADOR DAL. By Ian Gibson. (Norton, $45.) An evenhanded examination of the long and silly life (1904-89) of the Surrealist who cheapened and squandered his immense talent for an increasingly hollow, mercenary exhibitionism in his later years.

SIGHT-READINGS: American Fictions. By Elizabeth Hardwick. (Random House, $26.) Essays (her fourth collection) by a distinguished and durable critic, some of them venturing into delightful recollections about eminences like Edmund Wilson and Mary McCarthy.
SIR VIDIA'S SHADOW: A Friendship Across Five Continents. By Paul Theroux. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) The author recalls his turbulent friendship with V. S. Naipaul.

SKATING TO ANTARCTICA: A Journey to the End of the World. By Jenny Diski. (Ecco, $23.95.) A mightily disturbing memoir-cum-travel book in which the awful blankness and emptiness of the continent runs parallel with an excursion into the terrain of a remarkably unfortunate childhood.

SLAVE COUNTERPOINT: Black Culture in the Eighteenth-Century Chesapeake and Lowcountry. By Philip D. Morgan. (University of North Carolina, cloth, $49.95; paper, $21.95.) An impressive reconstruction of life in two areas of the South, and of how the slaves in both coped with circumstances and made sense of their lives.

SLAVES IN THE FAMILY. By Edward Ball. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) Through travel, interviews and documents, Ball, whose forebears owned thousands of slaves, grapples with his own sense of accountability for slavery and its consequences in this extended family chronicle, which won a National Book Award this year.

SOMEONE ELSE'S HOUSE: America's Unfinished Struggle for Integration. By Tamar Jacoby. (Free Press, $30.) An unrelenting, discouraging examination of three cities -- New York, Detroit and Atlanta -- where people of good and ill will combined to defeat the hopes of the 1960's.

SONG FOR THE BLUE OCEAN: Encounters Along the World's Coasts and Beneath the Seas. By Carl Safina. (John Macrae/Holt, $30.) An engrossing, illuminating, depressing journey, with a research ecologist, to the dwindling populations of wild edible creatures in the sea.
SOTHEBY'S -- BIDDING FOR CLASS. By Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The story of how a book-dealing business became an internationally glitzy auction house.

THE SPANISH INQUISITION: A Historical Revision. By Henry Kamen. (Yale University, $35.) The author finds that the Inquisition little resembled the omnipotent, torture-crazed blight imagined by 19th-century mythology.

SPLIT: A Counterculture Childhood. By Lisa Michaels. (Houghton Mifflin, $23.) A memoir (and first book) by a 31-year-old poet, essayist and child of the 60's; with her Weatherman father imprisoned in 1969, her mother took her west to a life of home-grown veggies and acoustic guitars.
STEPHEN SONDHEIM: A Life. By Meryle Secrest. (Knopf, $30.) The biography of the innovator of the Broadway musical.

THE STORY OF AMERICAN FREEDOM. By Eric Foner. (Norton, $27.95.) Freedom in America, this succinct, informative historian says, has meant many things, and has acquired new meanings through the struggles of those once excluded.

SUMMER OF DELIVERANCE: A Memoir of Father and Son. By Christopher Dickey. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) An angry, affectionate, hypnotic account of conflict and reconciliation between a son and his father, the brilliant literary celebrity and impassioned, inveterate liar James Dickey.

TAKING WING: Archaeopteryx and the Evolution of Bird Flight. By Pat Shipman. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The bird-and-dinosaur issue, lucidly handled by a writer who is able to understand and convey how paleontologists think.

A TANGLED WEB: The Making of Foreign Policy in the Nixon Presidency. By William Bundy. (Hill & Wang, $35.) A fair-minded and dispassionate assessment that gives Nixon higher marks for shrewdness and manipulation than for statesmanship.

TECUMSEH: A Life. By John Sugden. (John Macrae/Holt, $34.95.) A detailed, scrupulous account of the great leader who envisioned a pan-Indian alliance against the whites but came, inevitably, to grief in the War of 1812.

TENDER AT THE BONE: Growing Up at the Table. By Ruth Reichl. (Random House, $23.) The riotously amusing memoir, frankly somewhat embroidered, of a woman whose life of eating, waitressing and cooking prepared her for her current job as restaurant critic of this newspaper.

THE TENNIS PARTNER: A Doctor's Story of Friendship and Loss. By Abraham Verghese. (HarperCollins, $25.) A wise, lyrical, controlled narrative about tennis, medicine and friendship and their spiritual costs and benefits.

THREADS OF TIME: Recollections. By Peter Brook. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Counterpoint, $25.) A restless spirit and brilliant theatrical innovator describes his life, his influences (Brecht, Genet, Beckett; no surprises here) and his spiritual questing.

THURGOOD MARSHALL: American Revolutionary. By Juan Williams. (Times Books/Random House, $27.50.) A biography of a life devoted to the civil rights struggle, as a lawyer (who won the 1954 school desegregation decision) and as a jurist (the first black Justice on the Supreme Court).

THE TIME OF OUR TIME. By Norman Mailer. (Random House, $39.50.) A large anthology of his own work in the 50th year of ''The Naked and the Dead'' and the 75th of himself; a veritable social history of postwar America as Mailer (so often correctly) saw it and sometimes made it.

TOTALLY, TENDERLY, TRAGICALLY: Essays and Criticism From a Lifelong Love Affair With the Movies. By Phillip Lopate. (Anchor/Doubleday, paper, $12.95.) A collection of essays by one of the masters of the form detailing his involvement with film, from his student days to the present.

TOWARD ANOTHER SHORE: Russian Thinkers Between Necessity and Chance. By Aileen M. Kelly. (Yale University, $35.) An intellectual historian blames the West, as well as the Soviets, for conceiving the 19th-century Russian intelligentsia as a monolith of misfits.

TOWARDS A NEW MUSEUM. By Victoria Newhouse. (Monacelli, paper, $45.) An architectural historian of great range and scope provides a gatherum of ideas, questions, critiques and inspirations that are raised, or should be raised, by the museum boom of the last 30 years.

TRICKY DICK AND THE PINK LADY: Richard Nixon vs. Helen Gahagan Douglas -- Sexual Politics and the Red Scare, 1950. By Greg Mitchell. (Random House, $25.) An account of the Senate race that previewed the redbaiting that would mark the 1950's.

TROUBLE IN MIND: Black Southerners in the Age of Jim Crow. By Leon F. Litwack. (Knopf, $35.) A heartbreaking portrayal of segregation, disfranchisement and sheer meanness between Reconstruction and World War I.

TRUMAN CAPOTE. By George Plimpton. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $35.) An oral biography of the man whose literary gifts were rivaled only by his talent for self-promotion, this account takes Capote from his Southern boyhood to the New York literary whirl, and serves up dish that often reveals as much about the speaker as the subject.

TRUTH COMES IN BLOWS: A Memoir. By Ted Solotaroff. (Norton, $23.95.) A moving and intelligent recollection of life as the child of a selfish and heartless father and of a heroic and successful struggle to understand and forgive.

TURBULENT SOULS: A Catholic Son's Return to His Jewish Family. By Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $24.) The accurately observed and generously sympathetic histories of an American Jewish couple who became ardent Roman Catholics and their youngest child (of eight), who reversed the process; by that child himself.

TURNAROUND: How America's Top Cop Reversed the Crime Epidemic. By William Bratton with Peter Knobler. (Random House, $25.) Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's first Police Commissioner, apparently dismissed for shining too brightly in the news, gives his version of things.

TWILIGHT ON THE LINE: Underworlds and Politics at the U.S.-Mexican Border. By Sebastian Rotella. (Norton, $25.) A vivid study of immigration, crime and graft at a border pressurized by Federal agents' successful interdiction of the drug highway through Florida.

TWINS: And What They Tell Us About Who We Are. By Lawrence Wright. (Wiley, $22.95.) A lucid if not totally convincing introduction to behavioral genetics, based chiefly on studies of identical twins raised separately.

UNAFRAID OF THE DARK: A Memoir. By Rosemary L. Bray. (Random House, $24.) The life so far of a black woman who grew up on welfare (a system whose detractors she upbraids), went to Yale and became a successful journalist at this book review and many other places.
UNAUTHORIZED PORTRAITS. By Edward Sorel. (Knopf, $40.) A personal anthology by a cartoonist who is a foremost practitioner of what he calls ''comic portraits that are deliberately hurtful.''

UNDER A WING: A Memoir. By Reeve Lindbergh (Simon & Schuster, $23). A loving memoir about life with a father insistent on control and embarrassed by surprise; written by his youngest child (born 1945).

the unfinished presidency: Jimmy Carter's Journey Beyond the White House. By Douglas Brinkley. (Viking, $29.95.) The post-Washington years of the Chief Executive turned poet, housebuilder and tireless freelance crusader for human rights.

THE VICTORS. Eisenhower and His Boys: The Men of World War II. By Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) Eisenhower's biographer lucidly presents the campaign in Europe, including the gravity and unity of purpose that permitted the supreme commander to instruct lieutenants to be fathers to their men.

VIOLET: The Life and Loves of Violet Gordon Woodhouse. By Jessica Douglas-Home. (Harvill/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) With one lawful husband and three faithful surrogates, this remarkable Englishwoman lived one of the oddest happy lives of the Edwardian and Georgian eras.
VISIONS OF JAZZ: The First Century. By Gary Giddins. (Oxford University, $35.) This gigantic book of 79 essays amounts, willy-nilly, to a grand, brilliant history of the most American of arts.

WALKING WITH THE WIND: A Memoir of the Movement. By John Lewis with Michael D'Orso. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) An illustrious leader of the civil rights movement reflects on the auspicious transformation of the early 1960's and the deaths and disillusionment that followed.

THE WARRIOR'S HONOR: Ethnic War and the Modern Conscience. By Michael Ignatieff. (Metropolitan/Holt, $24.95.) In five uneasy essays, a commentator and moralist examines the near-impotence of the immensely powerful West to amend pointless savagery in less favored states.

WE'LL CALL YOU IF WE NEED YOU: Experiences of Women Working Construction. By Susan Eisenberg. (ILR Press/Cornell University, $25.) The author, a master electrician and poet, thoughtfully introduces and celebrates the people and the measures that led to the modest success women have achieved in the building trades.

WICKERBY: An Urban Pastoral. By Charles Siebert. (Crown, $21.) The poles of this memoir are Siebert's native Brooklyn and the landscape of southern Quebec, and its enterprise is the reunion through reflection of the city with nature.
WILD THOUGHTS FROM WILD PLACES. By David Quammen. (Scribner, $24.) A collection of magazine articles that allows the reader to share Quammen's love of nature.

WITH OSSIE AND RUBY: In This Life Together. By Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee. (Morrow, $25.) Recollections and observations about themselves, the black experience in the American theater and the many causes these remarkable actors have embraced in their 50 years together.

THE WORLD ACCORDING TO PETER DRUCKER. By Jack Beatty. (Free Press, $25.) Taking Drucker seriously as an intellectual, Beatty finds him ambivalent about capitalism, disappointed in management's social irresponsibility, and engaged with the thought of Kierkegaard.

A WORLD TRANSFORMED. By George Bush and Brent Scowcroft. (Knopf, $30.) The former President and his national security adviser articulate and defend the Bush foreign policy, of which an important element was the patience to avoid embarrassing Communism as it departed.

THE WORLD WITHIN WAR: America's Combat Experience in World War II. By Gerald F. Linderman. (Free Press, $26.) The experience and the remarkable effectiveness of ordinary Americans called to arms, reflectively told and based on memoirs and war fiction.

wormholes: Essays and Occasional Writings. By John Fowles. Edited by Jan Relf. (Holt, $25.) An elegant stylist, opinionated curmudgeon and author of ''The French Lieutenant's Woman,'' Fowles offers a retrospective collection of pieces encompassing travels in Greece (rapturous encomium) and Margaret Thatcher (vigorous castigation).

''YOU AIN'T HEARD NOTHIN' YET.'' The American Talking Film: History & Memory, 1927-1949. By Andrew Sarris. (Oxford University, $35.) Notes and essays covering films examined by as significant and missionary a critic as we've got.
CHILDREN

HOLES. By Louis Sachar. (Frances Foster Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.) (Ages 12 and up) In this comic novel of suspense and imagination, which won a National Book Award this year, Stanley Yelnats has been sent to a Texas juvenile correctional facility and is set to digging holes. Nothing is quite what it seems.

HURRY, HURRY, MARY DEAR. By N. M. Bodecker. Illustrated by Erik Blegvad. (Margaret K. McElderry, $16.) (Ages 7 and up) A witty verse about autumn chores has been illustrated with amusing detail and in the subtle colors of New England as the leaves fall and the skies darken.

I LOST MY BEAR. Written and illustrated by Jules Feiffer. (Morrow, $16.) (Ages 3 and up) A serious, and all too familiar, psychodrama told in comic style and complete with hysteria and satisfying resolution.

LOOK-ALIKES. By Joan Steiner. Photographed by Thomas Lindley. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) (Ages 3 and up) In the Universe of Stray Stuff there is order and imagination and great wit. Eleven dioramas made from hundreds of everyday objects require and reward close study.

NO PRETTY PICTURES: A Child of War. By Anita Lobel. (Greenwillow, $16.) (Ages 10 and up) The unsentimental and deeply moving story of this popular illustrator's childhood in World War II, moving through the concentration camps to recovery and adolescence in Sweden.

PETE'S A PIZZA. Written and illustrated by William Steig. (Michael di Capua/ HarperCollins, $13.95.) (All ages) A wonderful treatment for cranky children: roll 'em out, dust 'em off and turn 'em into pretend pizza. Deliciously funny.

SQUIDS WILL BE SQUIDS: Fresh Morals, Beastly Fables. By Jon Scieszka. Illustrated by Lane Smith. (Viking, $17.99.) (Ages 8 and up) Behind the irreverence and wise-guy tone, beyond the dark and stylish illustrations, these modern fables, giving human foibles to other creatures, have some shrewd observations.

THIS LAND IS YOUR LAND. Words and music by Woody Guthrie. Illustrated by Kathy Jakobsen. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) (All ages) A miniature panoramic setting of all of the verses of the song everyone thinks everybody knows, filled with details from Guthrie's life. Sing along.

VICTOR: A Novel Based on the Life of the Savage of Aveyron. By Mordicai Gerstein. (Frances Foster Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.) (Ages 12 and up) In telling the true story of the feral child found in the south of France in 1800 and the boy's life in Paris, the author addresses the question of what civilization is all about.

WHIRLIGIG. By Paul Fleischman. (Holt, $16.95.) (Ages 12 and up) Brent's journey to the four corners of the United States, to plant the whirligigs he has made to honor a girl he accidentally killed, is complex and beautifully told.
MYSTERIES

BACKFLASH. By Richard Stark. (Mysterious Press/ Warner, $20.) This dazzling crime caper (written by Donald E. Westlake in noir humor) follows the misadventures of a crack team of con men and killers who have worked out an ingenious scheme to rob a riverboat casino sailing up the Hudson River to Albany.

THE BALLAD OF FRANKIE SILVER. By Sharyn McCrumb. (Dutton, $23.95.) A case of 19th-century frontier justice and the modern-day execution of a killer are interwoven in this Appalachian mountain tale of love, loyalty and murder.

BEYOND RECALL. By Robert Goddard. (Holt, $25.) The elegant arc of this generational mystery takes the English narrator from a guilty confrontation with the childhood friend he abandoned, when a murder drove their families apart, to the exhumation of an old crime and unresolved issues of greed, betrayal and revenge.

BLIND DESCENT. By Nevada Barr. (Putnam, $22.95.) On a hair-raising mission into a ''monster man-eating cave'' in Carlsbad Caverns, a National Park Service ranger discovers that a member of her rescue team is a killer.

EVERYBODY DIES. By Lawrence Block. (Morrow, $25.) Matt Scudder finds some metaphysical questions to ponder when his gangster buddy Mick Ballou, the bloodthirsty but engaging owner of the last great Irish saloon in Hell's Kitchen, involves him in a brutal gang war.

FEVER SEASON. By Barbara Hambly. (Bantam, $23.95.) Set against the appalling spectacle of the yellow fever epidemic of 1834, the mystery of the freed slaves who are vanishing from New Orleans proves a dangerous puzzle for Benjamin January, a surgeon who takes the reader through the worst of the city's pestilential death houses.

NIGHT DOGS. By Kent Anderson. (Bantam, $22.95.) A street cop in Portland, Ore., works himself into a hellish state of mind as he pounds his wretched beat in 1975, reliving his own nightmares as a Green Beret in Vietnam.

ON BEULAH HEIGHT. By Reginald Hill. (Delacorte, $22.95.) Part murder mystery, part meditation on the love and loss of children, this tragic story sends detectives Dalziel and Pascoe into a Yorkshire village where a little girl's disappearance brings fresh grief to the parents of three other children who went missing 15 years ago.

SUNSET LIMITED. By James Lee Burke. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murky waters of the Louisiana bayou breed lurid crimes and revolting villains, prompting the Cajun detective David Robicheaux to brood about the fate of local characters like Cool Breeze, a luckless soul who ''tried to stay out of trouble but wouldn't nobody let him.''

WINGS OF FIRE. By Charles Todd. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $23.95.) The wild scenery and dark legends of the Cornish countryside provide the moody atmosphere for a Scotland Yard detective's investigation into the suicide of a beloved poet.
SCIENCE FICTION

ANTARCTICA. By Kim Stanley Robinson. (Spectra/ Bantam, $24.95). Robinson is at the top of his form in this near-future novel about the men and women who fall in love with the ice-bound continent and fight over its development. Like John McPhee, Robinson finds drama and poetry in the raw facts of geography and geology.

BLOOM. By Wil McCarthy. (Del Rey, $23.95). A journalist named John Strasheim finds himself on a journey to the heart of a ''technogenic'' organism that threatens to eat the solar system. Life's determination to survive, no matter what the consequences, is the theme of this rousing yet thoughtful adventure story.

THE CHILDREN STAR. By Joan Slonczewski. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $24.95). Are our conventional notions of intelligent life too narrow? To the well-meaning human colonists on the planet Prokaryon, the answer is a matter of life and death. The author, a biology professor with a strong feminist bent, has written a puzzle story that begins slowly but moves toward a climax filled with intellectual and emotional fireworks.

CIRCUIT OF HEAVEN. By Dennis Danvers. (Eos/Avon, $14.) ''Romeo and Juliet in Cyberspace'' might be the subtitle of this moving love story, in which technological barriers threaten to separate an appealing pair of ''star-cross'd lovers'' as painfully as the more traditional barriers of class and clan.

MOCKINGBIRD. By Sean Stewart. (Ace, $21.95). As in his previous ''Resurrection Man,'' Stewart writes about magic as if it were an everyday occurrence, with its own rules and reasons. Antoinette Beau-champ is an actuary with a sense of humor, an indispensable survival trait for the daughter of a witch who inherits powers she cannot control -- without a little help from her friends.

THIS ALIEN SHORE. By C. S. Friedman. (DAW, $23.95). Traveling faster than light warps the mind yet allows humans to fill the galaxy with new kinds of societies that tap the long-buried potential of the genome. Jamisia, a young girl on the run from interstellar plotters, turns out to be a key player in this breathlessly plotted, emotionally savvy space opera.
